comment.author: 45921043@N07
comment._content: I hope that the State Library of Queensland has an autographed photo of Strauss and Cook walking out to bat at the Gabba too!

comment.author: 24671619@N07
comment._content: Both of them had pretty neat handwriting !!

comment.author: 45921043@N07
comment._content: Everybody had neat handwriting then. Ball point pens hadn't been invented and fountain pens only worked properly if you wrote slowly. Handwriting practice was a key part of primary education in those days.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Jack Hobbs was one of the best ever, and the other bloke wasn't bad either. Fancy playing Jack Gregory wearing this kit! Spiky rubber batting gloves, 1920s lo-tech hip guards and presumably 1920s lo-tech protectors as well. Superb pic!

comment.author: 32605636@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] It's always interesting to look at sporting photos from the past and consider their achievements in light of the equipment that was used at the time. Glad you like this photo!

comment.author: 94956239@N05
comment._content: Read more about this image on the John Oxley Library blog blogs.slq.qld.gov.au/jol/2013/07/18/england-v-australia-1...

comment.author: 94956239@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Jack Gregory suffered a career ending knee injury in this match contributing to Australia's defeat by 675 runs.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/94956239@N05] I was hoping no one would mention the score (!) Hey Prof, given your knowledge of cricket, I wonder whether you might have any ideas on this pic...hope you don't mind me asking... www.flickr.com/photos/blue_mountains_library_-_local_stud... Cheers!

comment.author: 94956239@N05
comment._content: It is an intriguing puzzle but I am afraid I can offer no additional clues.  Good luck with your investigations quasymody
